info.game_comments:
Ken Jennings game 49.
The first regular play game of Season 21 to be recorded after the summer hiatus.

(1, 1).clue: Hunting & forest clearing (not a luxury automaker) have endangered this largest wild cat of the Americas

(2, 1).clue: A stadium with the world’s largest roof was built in 1972 for the Olympic games in this city

(3, 1).clue: There's plenty of room here for your groceries

(4, 1).clue: "CAD" stands for these 3 computer keys (often used together)

(5, 1).clue: The man he tied with 73 electoral votes in 1800

(6, 1).clue: AKA "America’s Dairyland", it’s one of the leading U.S. states in milk production

(1, 2).clue: Like an escargot, the abalone is an edible one of these gastropods

(2, 2).clue: On March 14, 1997 Scott Hamilton became the first figure skater inducted into this NYC sports arena’s Walk of Fame

(4, 2).clue: Don’t wait around if you read "DHYB"; it means “don’t hold” this

(5, 2).clue: The New Jersey college he graduated from at age 16

(6, 2).clue: 1 of this unit of milk weighs about 8 pounds

(1, 3).clue: It's the branch of physics that deals with the nature & properties of light

(2, 3).clue: Built in 1912, this American League park is Major League Baseball's oldest & smallest in capacity

(4, 3).clue: "ESO" is the insulting "equipment smarter than" this person

(5, 3).clue: The man he went to New Jersey to meet on July 11, 1804

(6, 3).clue: A Frenchman created this process that kills microorganisms in milk by heating it

(1, 4).clue: Hermann Muller won a 1946 Nobel Prize for proving that the use of these can cause mutations

(2, 4).clue: This Big 12 school plays its home basketball games at the Bob Devaney Sports Center

(4, 4).clue: "CD-ROM" also stands for "consumer device rendered" this "in months"

(5, 4).clue: The man he introduced the widow Dolley Todd to in 1794

(6, 4).clue: This type of sugar that's less sweet than sucrose is found only in milk

(1, 5).clue: The flowers on this type of myrtle tree resemble the crinkly paper of the same name

(2, 5).clue: (I'm Moe Williams from the NFL.)  The Minnesota Vikings play their home games in a domed stadium named for this former U.S. vice president

(4, 5).clue: "AIAMU" means "and I'm a" this, expressing astonishment

(5, 5).clue: The Chief Justice who presided over his treason trial

(6, 5).clue: In 1856 Gail Borden received a patent for his process to do this to milk

(1, 1).clue: Bush-Cheney called Edwards Kerry's second choice, meaning this Republican was his first

(2, 1).clue: In the 19th century a new breed of terrier was named for this clergyman

(3, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew strolls through an unfinished airplane cabin at the Boeing Everett Factory in Seattle, WA.)  I'm walking through this main body of the airplane, which gets its name from the Old French for "spindle"

(4, 1).clue: One of the principal exports of Seychelles is copra, the dried white flesh of this fruit

(5, 1).clue: A tree that's a national symbol of Slovenia, or a Texan U.S. president's first name

(6, 1).clue: On October 26, 1881 this took place at Tombstone's OK Corral

(1, 2).clue: George W. Bush won 91% of the vote in Massachusetts (unfortunately for him it was in this contest)

(2, 2).clue: In "Nightmares & Dreamscapes" this author wrote, "I believe there is an unseen world all around us"

(3, 2).clue: In chemistry, it maintains a mixture resistant to change; when flying it controls the pitch of an aircraft

(4, 2).clue: From about 1500 to 1750 the Seychelles served mainly as a hiding place for these people

(5, 2).clue: Loudly, raucously sound out George Orwell's original last name

(6, 2).clue: William Congreve wrote, "Women are like tricks by" this "of hand, which, to admire, we should not understand"

(1, 3).clue: Most of the over 50,000 signatures he submitted to try to get on the Michigan ballot were collected by the GOP

(2, 3).clue: In 1999 this rapper-turned-actress turned talk show host

(3, 3).clue: This 3-digit number, popular in Vegas slot machines, is Boeing's & the world's largest family of twinjet

(4, 3).clue: The Seychelles uses this unit of currency, which is also used in Pakistan, Nepal & Sri Lanka

(5, 3).clue: A critiquer of pure reason who died in 1804, or a response indicating you're unable to grasp his philosophy

(6, 3).clue: As a noun, it's a zero; as a pronoun, it's nothing

(1, 4).clue: In a July 23 speech to this league, the President asked if the Democrats take black voters for granted

(2, 4).clue: Columbia chief Harry Cohn advised this actor to change his last name to avoid negative review puns

(3, 4).clue: Greater than supersonic, it's the term for a speed 5 times faster than the speed of sound

(4, 4).clue: Seychelles is an example of this grouping of a large number of islands on a vast sheet of sea

(5, 4).clue: In "A hymn to God the Father", this metaphysical poet makes punning use of this synonym for "finished"

(6, 4).clue: Samuel F.B. Morse could have told you that it's a past tense & a past participle of work

(1, 5).clue: This Florida senator was the first Democratic candidate to drop out of the race

(2, 5).clue: An ad in a 1973 paper brought this lead guitarist together with Gene Simmons, Paul Stanley & Peter Criss

(3, 5).clue: "Air"y name of the curved top & flat bottom shape that airplane (& bird) wings have to give them lift

(4, 5).clue: This Portuguese navigator, the first European to reach India by sea, discovered the Seychelles in 1502

(5, 5).clue: Sadly for him, the 17th century gunpowder plotter wasn't quite as sly as the animal

(6, 5).clue: Abbreviated dwt., it's equal to 24 grains, or 1/20 of a troy ounce

(0, 0).clue: Called the 2 most innovative 19th century American poets, one didn't read the other after being "told that he was disgraceful"
